values.description: It will start automatically, though there are some timing issues. I tell it to wait 20 seconds before starting the grasping controller, but I'm not sure how reliable that will be.
values.title: add val_grasping controller to srcsim

values.description:
Add a model for the "leak", which can be detected by a logical camera on the air leak detector.

![leak.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/988194215-leak.png)

* The leak is a red sphere mostly for debugging, we can remove the visual later

* The leak is on layer 1, so you can use the left panel to hide it for now, if you wish

* This is not integrated into the checkpoint system on this PR, I'm trying to keep it short.

* I've removed the logic to place the leak on the habitat's wall until we have a final habitat 

### How to test it

1. Launch the world

        roslaunch srcsim unique.launch

1. Listen to the logical camera topic

        gz topic -e /gazebo/SRC_finals/air_leak_detector/base/logical_camera/models

1. At first the detector should only be seeing the `space_table`

1. Use the rotation tool to rotate the detector towards the leak, and the detector should see the leak too.
values.title: Task 3: Leak and detector sensor

summary.raw:
Add a model for the "leak", which can be detected by a logical camera on the air leak detector.

![leak.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/988194215-leak.png)

* The leak is a red sphere mostly for debugging, we can remove the visual later

* The leak is on layer 1, so you can use the left panel to hide it for now, if you wish

* This is not integrated into the checkpoint system on this PR, I'm trying to keep it short.

* I've removed the logic to place the leak on the habitat's wall until we have a final habitat 

### How to test it

1. Launch the world

        roslaunch srcsim unique.launch

1. Listen to the logical camera topic

        gz topic -e /gazebo/SRC_finals/air_leak_detector/base/logical_camera/models

1. At first the detector should only be seeing the `space_table`

1. Use the rotation tool to rotate the detector towards the leak, and the detector should see the leak too.
summary.html:
Add a model for the "leak", which can be detected by a logical camera on the air leak detector.

  • The leak is a red sphere mostly for debugging, we can remove the visual later

  • The leak is on layer 1, so you can use the left panel to hide it for now, if you wish

  • This is not integrated into the checkpoint system on this PR, I'm trying to keep it short.

  • I've removed the logic to place the leak on the habitat's wall until we have a final habitat

How to test it

  1. Launch the world

    roslaunch srcsim unique.launch

  2. Listen to the logical camera topic

    gz topic -e /gazebo/SRC_finals/air_leak_detector/base/logical_camera/models

  3. At first the detector should only be seeing the space_table

  4. Use the rotation tool to rotate the detector towards the leak, and the detector should see the leak too.

values.description:
_Sometimes_ Val hits the satellite as it is teleported, so this pull request makes her teleport 0.2 m further back, which should prevent that:

before | after 
-------- | ------
![skip13_before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1309376191-skip13_before.png) | ![skip13.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2400004726-skip13.png)

The only real change here is on the erb file from -2.2 to -2.4, the rest are generated files.

Also see the comments on issue #119
values.title: Task 1: Teleport Val a bit further from the satellite

values.description:
Add habitat model for task 3 and integrate it into the world.

![hab1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2915144268-hab1.png)

* There's a habitat SDF model mostly for reference and to have the model directory structure
* The `habitat.erb` file is where the collisions and the whole model structure are actually generated from
* Detailed simple collision shapes for the stairs and rails
* Simple collision shapes for floors and walls

    ![hab2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1709277528-hab2.png)

* There are two models, the `habitat_base` is a static model consisting of all the visuals except for the entrance door

* The `habitat_door` model is not static and consists of the door and the valve. It has 3 joints:
    * A fixed "lock" joint which will be removed once the valve is turned
    * A revolute joint for the valve, with the same range of friction as the satellite wheels

        ![habdoor.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/743741129-habdoor.gif)

    * A hinge joint with the world about which the door opens. If you want to try pushing the door, you can manually remove the lock joint from the world. The friction on the hinge helps the door remain open.

        ![habdoor2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3570344327-habdoor2.gif)

        I tried pushing it with Val and it looks reasonable:

        ![habdoor4.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1139374490-habdoor4.gif)

* Moved the table to be inside the habitat and added a point light inside so it's not very dark:

    ![hab6.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3009515305-hab6.png)

* Modified the heightmap so that there's room for the habitat (humans are always changing planets, right?)
values.title: Task 3: Habitat model

* The `habitat.erb` file is where the collisions and the whole model structure are actually generated from

* There are two models, the `habitat_base` is a static model consisting of all the visuals except for the entrance door

summary.html:
Add habitat model for task 3 and integrate it into the world.

  • There's a habitat SDF model mostly for reference and to have the model directory structure
  • The habitat.erb file is where the collisions and the whole model structure are actually generated from
  • Detailed simple collision shapes for the stairs and rails

  • Simple collision shapes for floors and walls

  • There are two models, the habitat_base is a static model consisting of all the visuals except for the entrance door

  • The habitat_door model is not static and consists of the door and the valve. It has 3 joints:

    • A fixed "lock" joint which will be removed once the valve is turned

    • A revolute joint for the valve, with the same range of friction as the satellite wheels

    • A hinge joint with the world about which the door opens. If you want to try pushing the door, you can manually remove the lock joint from the world. The friction on the hinge helps the door remain open.

      I tried pushing it with Val and it looks reasonable:

  • Moved the table to be inside the habitat and added a point light inside so it's not very dark:

  • Modified the heightmap so that there's room for the habitat (humans are always changing planets, right?)

values.description:
Addressing some of the concerns raised on issue #111:

* Brighter contrasting colors
* Different colors for each wheel
* Clockwise rotations increase angles
* Yaw on the right (blue), pitch on the left (red)

See it working here:

https://github.com/chapulina/gzgif/blob/master/satelite_colors.gif
values.title: Task 1: Update satellite colors and wheel directions

values.description:
This is broken off of pull request #57.

* Add everything needed for task 3, checkpoints 1 through 4
* It should be possible to perform the [tutorial](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/finals_task3) up to the completion of checkpoint 4 (but use `unique` instead of `unique_task3` for now)
* If you need hints on how to complete the checkpoints without controlling the robot, [this](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gUsyCfwlNGw) video should help
* Skipping checkpoints should behave as described [here](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/skip_summary)

values.description:
This is broken off of pull request #57.

* Randomize table position inside habitat in a way that it's always around the center
* Randomize tools positions on top of the table
* Add stacks of crates around the habitat so that they:
    * don't collide with the table
    * stay a bit away from the walls
    * might be immediately in front of doors, but there's still room to move around them
    * there's always one stack near the wall with the leak

![t3_random.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/497788305-t3_random.png)

Keep in mind that these scripts are mainly there for convenience, they might not generate perfect worlds 100% of the time. I'm also open to suggestions on how to make the habitat more exciting.
values.title: Task 3: Randomize habitat objects

values.description:
This builds on top of ~~pull request #57~~

* Add `finals.launch`, which is the file launched by CloudSim during practice and finals
* `finals.launch` differs from `unique.launch`:
    * `init` is true by default
    * `gui` is false by default sop gzclient is not launched
    * it accepts a `final_number` argument with numbers from 1 to 5 to choose which world to launch
* Generated 5 sample worlds for practice. The real ones will not be made public before the finals.

Usage:

`roslaunch srcsim finals.launch final_number:=2`
values.title: Launch file and 5 example worlds for finals

* Generated 5 sample worlds for practice. The real ones will not be made public before the finals.

Usage:

`roslaunch srcsim finals.launch final_number:=2`

Usage:

values.description:
See issue #138

* Moved the solar panel on `unique_task2.world` so that it's within reach.

* Adjusted the randomizing script so these are the limits of where it can be teleported:

Boundary | 0 | Pi / 2
------------ | -- | -----
max y | ![max_y_panel.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/440048667-max_y_panel.png) | ![max_y_panel_rot.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2039896112-max_y_panel_rot.png)
min y | ![min_y_panel.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1816543773-min_y_panel.png) | ![min_y_panel_rot.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3660147658-min_y_panel_rot.png)

values.description:
I'm not sure when it happened, but the habitat mesh has slightly changed in a way that the wall collisions don't fit as nicely anymore. This is mainly an issue for the wall which has the leak, so I just fixed that one. 

Now you can see the collision nicely matching the visual and the leak sticking out. The screenshot is harder to understand than actually looking at the mesh though...

![leakcollision.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1850412866-leakcollision.png)

values.description:
This is starting to address issue #135, regarding performance.

This makes it so the habitat starts empty and is only populated when task 3 checkpoint 3 starts. This means we're not calculating contacts between the tools and the table until then, none of their sensors and plugins have been loaded, and in general, less models means better performance.

Conversely, when task 3 checkpoint 4 starts, all models outside of the habitat are deleted.

Locally, I've seen an improvement on the real time factor in the beginning of a run from around 0.14 closer to 0.21

### How to test it

1. Start `unique.launch`

        roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true

1. Wait for `Init: Done`

1. Look inside the habitat and check that there are no models.

1. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 3:

        rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 3

1. Look inside the habitat and check that the table and the tools and a bunch of crates were spawned.

1. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 4:

        rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

1. Look outside the habitat, all models should have been deleted (sometimes there might be one bling left, in case the world has 15 instead of 14 blings outside)
values.title: Performance: Delete / insert models as we need them in view

summary.raw:
This is starting to address issue #135, regarding performance.

This makes it so the habitat starts empty and is only populated when task 3 checkpoint 3 starts. This means we're not calculating contacts between the tools and the table until then, none of their sensors and plugins have been loaded, and in general, less models means better performance.

Conversely, when task 3 checkpoint 4 starts, all models outside of the habitat are deleted.

Locally, I've seen an improvement on the real time factor in the beginning of a run from around 0.14 closer to 0.21

### How to test it

1. Start `unique.launch`

        roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true

1. Wait for `Init: Done`

1. Look inside the habitat and check that there are no models.

1. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 3:

        rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 3

1. Look inside the habitat and check that the table and the tools and a bunch of crates were spawned.

1. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 4:

        rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

1. Look outside the habitat, all models should have been deleted (sometimes there might be one bling left, in case the world has 15 instead of 14 blings outside)
summary.html:
This is starting to address issue #135, regarding performance.

This makes it so the habitat starts empty and is only populated when task 3 checkpoint 3 starts. This means we're not calculating contacts between the tools and the table until then, none of their sensors and plugins have been loaded, and in general, less models means better performance.

Conversely, when task 3 checkpoint 4 starts, all models outside of the habitat are deleted.

Locally, I've seen an improvement on the real time factor in the beginning of a run from around 0.14 closer to 0.21

How to test it

  1. Start unique.launch

    roslaunch srcsim unique.launch init:=true

  2. Wait for Init: Done

  3. Look inside the habitat and check that there are no models.

  4. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 3:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 3

  5. Look inside the habitat and check that the table and the tools and a bunch of crates were spawned.

  6. Skip to Task 3, Checkpoint 4:

    rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

  7. Look outside the habitat, all models should have been deleted (sometimes there might be one bling left, in case the world has 15 instead of 14 blings outside)

values.description:
This PR adds the ability to re-harness Valkyrie to any desired pose. Previously, the harness was provided by gazebo's `HarnessPlugin` that has a gazebo topic interface, and the `gazebo_ros_harness` plugin that adds a ros interface. The changes to enable re-harnessing broke the ABI of the `HarnessPlugin`, so I forked them into this repository, while the changes will be sent upstream to gazebo's default branch.

In the VRC, we had an environment variables called `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED` that needed to be set to `1` in order for teleportation to be used. We should probably do the same for the ros harness attach topic, since it involves teleportation. We will provide an official method for re-harnessing, but we should probably use the gazebo topic interface for that.

Here's a quick example command for sending a re-harness command; feel free to tinker with the pose arguments:

~~~
rostopic pub --once \
  /valkyrie/harness/attach \
  geometry_msgs/Pose \
  '{position: {x: 5.77, y: -1.31, z: 4.5 }, orientation: {w: 1, x: 0, y: 0, z: 0}}'
~~~

I forgot to mention that you have to update the valkyrie urdf in order to use this; change the `libgazebo_ros_harness.so` to `libsrcsim_ros_harness.so`: [available in this gist](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/18c47ae2b0d4e8c2d339df88daa922e9)
values.title: Allow re-harnessing of valkyrie

summary.raw:
This PR adds the ability to re-harness Valkyrie to any desired pose. Previously, the harness was provided by gazebo's `HarnessPlugin` that has a gazebo topic interface, and the `gazebo_ros_harness` plugin that adds a ros interface. The changes to enable re-harnessing broke the ABI of the `HarnessPlugin`, so I forked them into this repository, while the changes will be sent upstream to gazebo's default branch.

In the VRC, we had an environment variables called `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED` that needed to be set to `1` in order for teleportation to be used. We should probably do the same for the ros harness attach topic, since it involves teleportation. We will provide an official method for re-harnessing, but we should probably use the gazebo topic interface for that.

Here's a quick example command for sending a re-harness command; feel free to tinker with the pose arguments:

~~~
rostopic pub --once \
  /valkyrie/harness/attach \
  geometry_msgs/Pose \
  '{position: {x: 5.77, y: -1.31, z: 4.5 }, orientation: {w: 1, x: 0, y: 0, z: 0}}'
~~~

I forgot to mention that you have to update the valkyrie urdf in order to use this; change the `libgazebo_ros_harness.so` to `libsrcsim_ros_harness.so`: [available in this gist](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/18c47ae2b0d4e8c2d339df88daa922e9)
summary.html:
This PR adds the ability to re-harness Valkyrie to any desired pose. Previously, the harness was provided by gazebo's HarnessPlugin that has a gazebo topic interface, and the gazebo_ros_harness plugin that adds a ros interface. The changes to enable re-harnessing broke the ABI of the HarnessPlugin, so I forked them into this repository, while the changes will be sent upstream to gazebo's default branch.

In the VRC, we had an environment variables called VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED that needed to be set to 1 in order for teleportation to be used. We should probably do the same for the ros harness attach topic, since it involves teleportation. We will provide an official method for re-harnessing, but we should probably use the gazebo topic interface for that.

Here's a quick example command for sending a re-harness command; feel free to tinker with the pose arguments:

rostopic pub --once \
  /valkyrie/harness/attach \
  geometry_msgs/Pose \
  '{position: {x: 5.77, y: -1.31, z: 4.5 }, orientation: {w: 1, x: 0, y: 0, z: 0}}'

I forgot to mention that you have to update the valkyrie urdf in order to use this; change the libgazebo_ros_harness.so to libsrcsim_ros_harness.so: available in this gist

values.description: I created a new `Score` message since the existing `Task` message contains only the information from a single task which isn't sufficient for scoring "streaks" of consecutive checkpoints across different tasks.

values.description:
By passing the variable BUILD_MSGS_ONLY to the catkin build line
(as in "catkin_make -DBUILD_MSGS_ONLY=true install"), the build
will only generate the code for the messages and services.  This
allows teams to build the messages without installing all of the
dependencies for the rest of SRCSIM.
values.title: Add a CMake parameter for building messages and services only.

summary.raw:
By passing the variable BUILD_MSGS_ONLY to the catkin build line
(as in "catkin_make -DBUILD_MSGS_ONLY=true install"), the build
will only generate the code for the messages and services.  This
allows teams to build the messages without installing all of the
dependencies for the rest of SRCSIM.
summary.html: By passing the variable BUILD_MSGS_ONLY to the catkin build line (as in "catkin_make -DBUILD_MSGS_ONLY=true install"), the build will only generate the code for the messages and services. This allows teams to build the messages without installing all of the dependencies for the rest of SRCSIM.

values.description:
This adds a robot_state_publisher to the multisense camera.
Note: this will work even better once we get the latest `ihmc_valkyrie_ros` that doesn't publish them https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_valkyrie_ros/commit/1d6ac01bca4195ac37c2f3a913c5e7df09a2580c

I didnt modify the logic of relaying the topics published by the multisense.
I could use some input on the camera topics we expose to users. My understanding is that we are publishing the same colored pointcloud on 2 different topics [here](#!/osrf/srcsim/src/0cf9854d17153514a51041e569f0a66b6e58b52c/launch/unique_task3.launch?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#unique_task3.launch-59:73). To do so we create 2 ROS nodes that listen to a colored pointcloud and publish it on 2 topics: `/multisense/image_points2` and `/multisense/image_points2_color`

Looking at the [multisense doc](http://docs.carnegierobotics.com/SL/api.html#api) it looks like `/multisense/image_points2` is meant to be a grayscale pointcloud and `/multisense/image_points2_color` a colored one. 

My suggestion: don't publish anything on `/multisense/image_points2` and publish the colored pointcloud directly on `/multisense/image_points2_color`. We can use the ROS remapping functionality to do so, this would avoid creating these 2 relay nodes and allow the message to be sent only once rather than 4 times.

Thoughts?
values.title: Publish multisense transforms

summary.raw:
This adds a robot_state_publisher to the multisense camera.
Note: this will work even better once we get the latest `ihmc_valkyrie_ros` that doesn't publish them https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_valkyrie_ros/commit/1d6ac01bca4195ac37c2f3a913c5e7df09a2580c

I didnt modify the logic of relaying the topics published by the multisense.
I could use some input on the camera topics we expose to users. My understanding is that we are publishing the same colored pointcloud on 2 different topics [here](#!/osrf/srcsim/src/0cf9854d17153514a51041e569f0a66b6e58b52c/launch/unique_task3.launch?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#unique_task3.launch-59:73). To do so we create 2 ROS nodes that listen to a colored pointcloud and publish it on 2 topics: `/multisense/image_points2` and `/multisense/image_points2_color`

Looking at the [multisense doc](http://docs.carnegierobotics.com/SL/api.html#api) it looks like `/multisense/image_points2` is meant to be a grayscale pointcloud and `/multisense/image_points2_color` a colored one. 

My suggestion: don't publish anything on `/multisense/image_points2` and publish the colored pointcloud directly on `/multisense/image_points2_color`. We can use the ROS remapping functionality to do so, this would avoid creating these 2 relay nodes and allow the message to be sent only once rather than 4 times.

Thoughts?
summary.html:
This adds a robot_state_publisher to the multisense camera. Note: this will work even better once we get the latest ihmc_valkyrie_ros that doesn't publish them https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_valkyrie_ros/commit/1d6ac01bca4195ac37c2f3a913c5e7df09a2580c

I didnt modify the logic of relaying the topics published by the multisense. I could use some input on the camera topics we expose to users. My understanding is that we are publishing the same colored pointcloud on 2 different topics here. To do so we create 2 ROS nodes that listen to a colored pointcloud and publish it on 2 topics: /multisense/image_points2 and /multisense/image_points2_color

Looking at the multisense doc it looks like /multisense/image_points2 is meant to be a grayscale pointcloud and /multisense/image_points2_color a colored one.

My suggestion: don't publish anything on /multisense/image_points2 and publish the colored pointcloud directly on /multisense/image_points2_color. We can use the ROS remapping functionality to do so, this would avoid creating these 2 relay nodes and allow the message to be sent only once rather than 4 times.

Thoughts?

values.description:
This doubles the simulation speed. I've also increased the speed at which the harness is lowered so it is ready sooner.

The speed gains enabled here are only fully realized if the lockstep wait times are reduced in val_gazebo:

* https://gitlab.com/scpeters/val_gazebo/commit/eafd38e4c210212ce18ec8c48eba23b20e7b5a63

# issue #154

Added a choke to the cable, it should make it easier to pick it up

![choke3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3952686112-choke3.png)
![choke2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3958359960-choke2.png)

* 3 cylinders for visual and for collision
* narrowest cylinder is the one which needs to touch the panel outlet to be plugged

# issue #144

Lifted the solar array and the table 0.2 m so that they're more comfortable to reach

![array1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3997221921-array1.png)
![table_high.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1128275303-table_high.png)

* Stretched meshes 0.2 m down
* Placed all objects which go on top of array and table 0.2 m higher
* This also helps with issue #153

values.description: There is a problem when playing back log files if the world file has `<sdf>` tags inside it, see [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2281/log-playback-fails-if-there-is-an-tag-in) Gazebo issue.
values.title: Logging: remove <sdf> from <plugin>

summary.raw: There is a problem when playing back log files if the world file has `<sdf>` tags inside it, see [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2281/log-playback-fails-if-there-is-an-tag-in) Gazebo issue.
summary.html: There is a problem when playing back log files if the world file has <sdf> tags inside it, see this Gazebo issue.

values.description:
* Add `HarnessManager`
* Re-harness when skipping checkpoints (addresses #170)
* Add ability to restart the current checkpoint
    * Re-harness back to beginning of current checkpoint
    * Time keeps running
    * Score combo is reset (@dirk-thomas, ptal)
    * This can be used when Val falls to get her back up, solving issue #104
* Publish harness ROS message on `/srcsim/finals/harness` with current harness state (addresses #175)
* Use harness manager on startup, so we don't need `init_robot.sh` or to set `init:=true` anymore

I'll be updating the tutorials as this is being reviewed.
values.title: Re-harness

summary.raw:
* Add `HarnessManager`
* Re-harness when skipping checkpoints (addresses #170)
* Add ability to restart the current checkpoint
    * Re-harness back to beginning of current checkpoint
    * Time keeps running
    * Score combo is reset (@dirk-thomas, ptal)
    * This can be used when Val falls to get her back up, solving issue #104
* Publish harness ROS message on `/srcsim/finals/harness` with current harness state (addresses #175)
* Use harness manager on startup, so we don't need `init_robot.sh` or to set `init:=true` anymore

I'll be updating the tutorials as this is being reviewed.
summary.html:
• Add HarnessManager
  • Re-harness when skipping checkpoints (addresses #170)
  • Add ability to restart the current checkpoint
    • Re-harness back to beginning of current checkpoint
    • Time keeps running
    • Score combo is reset (@dirk-thomas, ptal)
    • This can be used when Val falls to get her back up, solving issue #104
  • Publish harness ROS message on /srcsim/finals/harness with current harness state (addresses #175)
  • Use harness manager on startup, so we don't need init_robot.sh or to set init:=true anymore

I'll be updating the tutorials as this is being reviewed.

values.description:
I often get controller lockups when launching srcsim on the cloud and that results in a RTF of 0.0. Making the grasping controller wait for the ihmc wholebody controller seems to improve the initialization process.

I had tried to check for the `ihmc_valkyrie_control_java_bridge` to be ready by doing `rosservice call /controller_manager/list_controllers` but occasionally this causes the controller manager to freeze..
values.title: Wait for ihmc controller to be ready before launching grasp controller

summary.raw:
I often get controller lockups when launching srcsim on the cloud and that results in a RTF of 0.0. Making the grasping controller wait for the ihmc wholebody controller seems to improve the initialization process.

I had tried to check for the `ihmc_valkyrie_control_java_bridge` to be ready by doing `rosservice call /controller_manager/list_controllers` but occasionally this causes the controller manager to freeze..
summary.html:
I often get controller lockups when launching srcsim on the cloud and that results in a RTF of 0.0. Making the grasping controller wait for the ihmc wholebody controller seems to improve the initialization process.

I had tried to check for the ihmc_valkyrie_control_java_bridge to be ready by doing rosservice call /controller_manager/list_controllers but occasionally this causes the controller manager to freeze..

values.description:
Some things to check when reviewing:

* Times in `checkpoint_durations` correspond to the duration of the checkpoint
* Times in `checkpoint_penalties` add up when restarting and skipping
* Elapsed time includes penalties for all CPs in the task
* Timeout when `elapsed + penalties > timeout`
* Score streak is reset on both skip and restart
* Previous penalty carries over from previous task
* Total time counts only completed checkpoints, and their penalties

This builds on top of pull request #79
values.title: Time penalties on skip and reset

* Score streak is reset on both skip and restart
* Previous penalty carries over from previous task

values.description:
This should make it much easier and more efficient to check the scoring logic:


```
rostopic pub /srcsim/finals/force_checkpoint_completion std_msgs/Empty -1
```


Note: the ROS subscriber should be disabled for the competition though!

values.description:
Addresses issue #187.

I believe the arm gets caught on the valve because currently both the arm and the valve use trimesh collisions. The hand uses simple shape primitives, so it doesn't get caught in the valve.

With the pull request, we have the following contacts:

contact | collision 1 | collision 2
-- | -- | --
hand - valve | primitives | primitives
arm - valve | trimeshes | primitives

![valve.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/459286369-valve.png)
values.title: Task 3: Simple shape collisions for valve

summary.raw:
Addresses issue #187.

I believe the arm gets caught on the valve because currently both the arm and the valve use trimesh collisions. The hand uses simple shape primitives, so it doesn't get caught in the valve.

With the pull request, we have the following contacts:

contact | collision 1 | collision 2
-- | -- | --
hand - valve | primitives | primitives
arm - valve | trimeshes | primitives

![valve.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/459286369-valve.png)
summary.html:
Addresses issue #187.

I believe the arm gets caught on the valve because currently both the arm and the valve use trimesh collisions. The hand uses simple shape primitives, so it doesn't get caught in the valve.

With the pull request, we have the following contacts:

contact collision 1 collision 2
hand - valve primitives primitives
arm - valve trimeshes primitives

values.description:
See issue #205

This fix feels a bit hacky. The problem is that `ApplyPenaltyTime` calls `Restart` on the current checkpoint, which has teleporting effects on the 1st checkpoint of each task. This PR makes it so the restart is called before the skip, so that the new goal is overridden.

If anyone can think of a more elegant way of solving the issue, feel free to directly edit this PR.

@dirk-thomas , do you think you could take a quick look?
values.title: Fix skipping before leaving the start box

summary.raw:
See issue #205

This fix feels a bit hacky. The problem is that `ApplyPenaltyTime` calls `Restart` on the current checkpoint, which has teleporting effects on the 1st checkpoint of each task. This PR makes it so the restart is called before the skip, so that the new goal is overridden.

If anyone can think of a more elegant way of solving the issue, feel free to directly edit this PR.

@dirk-thomas , do you think you could take a quick look?
summary.html:
See issue #205

This fix feels a bit hacky. The problem is that ApplyPenaltyTime calls Restart on the current checkpoint, which has teleporting effects on the 1st checkpoint of each task. This PR makes it so the restart is called before the skip, so that the new goal is overridden.

If anyone can think of a more elegant way of solving the issue, feel free to directly edit this PR.

@dirk-thomas , do you think you could take a quick look?

values.description: A hack to fix the multisense joint states uses the joint state publisher, but this isn't installed by default, so we should depend on it. Thanks to @iche033 for noticing this.
values.title: add exec_depend on joint_state_publisher for multisense hack

summary.raw: A hack to fix the multisense joint states uses the joint state publisher, but this isn't installed by default, so we should depend on it. Thanks to @iche033 for noticing this.
summary.html: A hack to fix the multisense joint states uses the joint state publisher, but this isn't installed by default, so we should depend on it. Thanks to @iche033 for noticing this.

values.description:
This may help with issue #186. 

The current 45 degrees walkway has 2 overlapping collision boxes, which could be "collision z fighting" and generating flickering contacts. That walkway is hosted on the Gazebo model database.

This pull request forks the walkway model and substitutes the collisions with a single polyline collision, so there is no overlap.

Before and after:

![polywire.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2195084526-polywire.png)
values.title: Polyline collision for 45 degrees walkway

This may help with issue #186.

The current 45 degrees walkway has 2 overlapping collision boxes, which could be "collision z fighting" and generating flickering contacts. That walkway is hosted on the Gazebo model database.

This pull request forks the walkway model and substitutes the collisions with a single polyline collision, so there is no overlap.

Before and after:

values.description:
Another alternative to fix issue #186.

* Removed all collisions from walkway models
* Ported walkways from model database to this repo
* The world generator script now generates a polyline collision for the whole walkway at once

![walk.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3690080157-walk.png)

* It seems to work well on the great majority of cases, but the triangulation fails for some specific cases. For example, using seed 7 to generate the world, it fails because of this region:

![failgts.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1169123567-failgts.png)

* For all the existing worlds, the only one which failed was `unique_task2`, so I generated it with a new seed.
values.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

![walk.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3690080157-walk.png)

* It seems to work well on the great majority of cases, but the triangulation fails for some specific cases. For example, using seed 7 to generate the world, it fails because of this region:

summary.html:
Another alternative to fix issue #186.

  • Removed all collisions from walkway models
  • Ported walkways from model database to this repo
  • The world generator script now generates a polyline collision for the whole walkway at once

  • It seems to work well on the great majority of cases, but the triangulation fails for some specific cases. For example, using seed 7 to generate the world, it fails because of this region:

  • For all the existing worlds, the only one which failed was unique_task2, so I generated it with a new seed.

values.reason: Polylines have worse contacts than boxes and should be avoided as much as possible

values.description:
The feet can get tangled up when reharnessing, so this PR resets joint positions just before lowering. I got the neutral joint positions by echoing the joint_states when it seemed to be at equilibrium.

For a kinda weird reason, I don't reset the joints connecting the pelvis to the torso. The `pelvis` is the root of the urdf kinematic tree, but the torso is link attached to the harness. The [Joint::SetPosition](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42215f2019f5ae64fc8a0610ef804a0fc53b0740/gazebo/physics/Joint.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Joint.hh-347) function sets the child link poses down the entire kinematic chain, but this doesn't work since the torso pose is already constrained by the harness. To reset the torso joints, one would have to teleport the robot to a place with no other collisions nearby, then call `SetJointPosition` on all the joints, then attach the harness. Making this change would require a lot more code to be touched, so I think this is a good compromise. The legs will still swing down into place even if the torso joints aren't reset, but they should be untangled.

Intended to address #207 and #241.
values.title: Reset joint positions after harnessing (all except the torso joints)

summary.raw:
The feet can get tangled up when reharnessing, so this PR resets joint positions just before lowering. I got the neutral joint positions by echoing the joint_states when it seemed to be at equilibrium.

For a kinda weird reason, I don't reset the joints connecting the pelvis to the torso. The `pelvis` is the root of the urdf kinematic tree, but the torso is link attached to the harness. The [Joint::SetPosition](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/42215f2019f5ae64fc8a0610ef804a0fc53b0740/gazebo/physics/Joint.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Joint.hh-347) function sets the child link poses down the entire kinematic chain, but this doesn't work since the torso pose is already constrained by the harness. To reset the torso joints, one would have to teleport the robot to a place with no other collisions nearby, then call `SetJointPosition` on all the joints, then attach the harness. Making this change would require a lot more code to be touched, so I think this is a good compromise. The legs will still swing down into place even if the torso joints aren't reset, but they should be untangled.

Intended to address #207 and #241.
summary.html:
The feet can get tangled up when reharnessing, so this PR resets joint positions just before lowering. I got the neutral joint positions by echoing the joint_states when it seemed to be at equilibrium.

For a kinda weird reason, I don't reset the joints connecting the pelvis to the torso. The pelvis is the root of the urdf kinematic tree, but the torso is link attached to the harness. The Joint::SetPosition function sets the child link poses down the entire kinematic chain, but this doesn't work since the torso pose is already constrained by the harness. To reset the torso joints, one would have to teleport the robot to a place with no other collisions nearby, then call SetJointPosition on all the joints, then attach the harness. Making this change would require a lot more code to be touched, so I think this is a good compromise. The legs will still swing down into place even if the torso joints aren't reset, but they should be untangled.

Intended to address #207 and #241.
